channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #113 - Object Oriented Perl
item.description:
Hi,

It seems the development of p5-mop (a subset of Moose in core Perl) has inspired a few people. Even though it is at least 1-2 years till it becomes ready for production code. This week we have 3 related articles.

I have also started to experiment adding a few more links in the comment section of the newsletter. What do you think about those?

item.title: We're Hiring Telecommuters - Grant Street Group
item.description:
We are a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
Email resume:Â 106686-CS-6734@grantstreet.hrmdirect.com

item.title: Frankfurter Perl-Community Workshop 2013
item.description: There is going to be a Perl Community Workshop in Frankfurt, Germany on October 26-27, 2013. The announcement is in German.

item.title: Helios 2.61 Released
item.description: Helios is an synchronous distributed job processing system.

item.title: Hacking Hiveminder
item.description: Hiveminder is a collaborative todo list 'in the cloud', that can be used even if you only collaborate with yourself. It offers and API wrapped in Net::Hiveminder. Yanick Champoux has started to build a new, Perl based client. First for the command line, with later plans to create his own web interface. See the explanation how the command line interface was built.

item.title: Underappreciated Perl Code - Test::More::subtest()
item.description: Maintaining the number of tests can be a real pain, and running tests in parallel can confuse the parser. Timm Murray from the Wumpus Cave show how the subtest feature of Test::More can solve the former, and has an example how the latter might be solved.

item.title: CPAN Testers Summary - Die Mensch-Maschine
item.description: The monthly report from the CPAN Testers service.

item.title: Breaking users of old versions of a module
item.description: An interesting article by Steven Haryanto discussing how to handle backward incompatible changes. One of the approach is to keep the old behavior in a separated module and allow the user to specify which behavior they want to have at the use-time of the module.

item.title: How to Load YAML Config Files
item.description: David Farrell shows how to use the LoadFile function of YAML::XS and how to access the data after loading it.

item.title: Perl objects round up
item.description: Tim Heaney (oylenshpeegul) has implemented a simple class with 2 attributes, and a subclass inheriting from it in 7 different ways: vanilla Perl, using Object::Tiny, Moo, Moose, MooseX::Declare, Moops and the current version of p5-mop, called p5-mop-redux. In such a small example it is quite easy to see the differences among these approaches. (Discuss it on reddit.)

item.title: Poor Mans Jobqueue for Catalyst Apps
item.description: What happen, if you need to run a long process in a web app? There are plenty of established solutions for this, but David Schmidt decided to use his database to manage the queue.

item.title: Perl Catalyst - Hamburg Status and the Future
item.description: John Napiorkowski explains why did he change the release policy of Catalyst to have a development release after each quest has been completed: 'it would help inspire contributors since there's nothing better than to see you code live on CPAN'. So far 3 out of 7 quests for the Hamburg release have been completed.

item.title: p5-mop: a gentle introduction
item.description: Damien Krotkine provides a little background for p5-mop and explains why is it important to try it now, while it is still in development. He also gives examples, how to try it. (There is also a copy if this post on blogs.perl.org with some further comments.)

item.title: On porting a Moose module
item.description: Stevan Little, the author of Moose and main force behind p5-mop further discusses how he has been porting Bread::Board to use the new, and still under development p5-mop.

item.title: Material from the Rakudo and NQP Internals course
item.description: Jonathan Worthington writes about the 2-day course he ran a few weeks ago and links to the material that was released under Creative Commons license.

item.title: The MAIN subroutine in Perl 6
item.description: Konrad Borowski, who you might know from the weekly report about Perl 6, started a new series of articles about Perl 6. In a style, the first one is about the MAIN subroutine which adds command line handle handling to your script.

item.title: YAPC::Asia Tokyo 2013 is over
item.description: Daisuke Maki (lestrrat) who ran the biggest Perl events in the world decided to retire from this volunteer position. YAPC::Asia is looking for a leader and an organizer!

item.title: Talks from Kiev
item.description: Dave Cross has posted a collection of the videos covering his own talks at YAPC::EU in Kiev.

item.title: Understanding recursive subroutines - traversing a directory tree
item.description: Traversing a directory tree is a very good example to explain recursion. Certainly more natural than Fibonacci of factorial.

item.title: Traversing the filesystem - using a queue
item.description: Solving the same problem as above, but this time using a queue.

item.title: OSDC.fr
item.description: October 4-5, 2013, Paris, France

item.title: The Pittsburgh Perl Workshop
item.description: October 4-6, 2013, Pittsburgh, PA, USA

item.title: Portuguese Perl Workshop
item.description: October 9-10, 2013, Lisbon, Portugal

item.title: OSDC NZ
item.description: October 21-23, 2013, Auckland, New Zealand
